title: Why do people fear the wrong things? - Gerd Gigerenzer

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between relative risk and absolute risk?

options.label: A
options.text: Relative risk is the likelihood of an event occurring, while absolute risk is the number of people affected by that event.

options.label: B
options.text: Relative risk is the number of people affected by an event, while absolute risk is the likelihood of an event occurring.

options.label: C
options.text: Relative risk is a percentage, while absolute risk is a rate.

options.label: D
options.text: Relative risk is a rate, while absolute risk is a percentage.

multiple-choice.question: A review in 2009 found that mammography screenings reduced the number of breast cancer deaths from 5 women in 1,000 to 4. What is the absolute risk reduction?

A new drug reduces the risk of heart attacks by 40%. If out of a group of 1,000 people who didn't take the new drug, 10 would have heart attacks, what is the absolute risk of heart attacks if they take the drug?
Suppose the heart-attack drug caused cancer in one half of 1% of patients. If a group of 1,000 people took the drug, how many new cases of cancer would there be?

When evaluating risk, personal circumstances can affect individual evaluations of risk. What might motivate someone to take a medication that would lower their heart-attack risk, even if it only provides a small reduction in absolute risk?

options.label: A
options.text: Knowing they have a family history of heart disease

options.label: B
options.text: Knowing they have a high income

options.label: C
options.text: Knowing they have a low income

options.label: D
options.text: Knowing they have a high level of education

options.label: C

options.label: C
options.text: Their strength and seaworthiness.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: They were unable to build ships that could withstand rough seas.
